PREFACE
The type of poetry commonly known as heroic is one which makes its
appearance in various nations and in various periods of history. No
one can fail to observe that certain similar features are to be found
in poems of this type which are widely separated from one another both
in date and place of origin. In view of this fact it has seemed worth
while to attempt a comparative study of two groups of such poems with
the object of determining the nature of the resemblances between them
and the causes to which they are due. Occasional illustrations have
been taken from other groups of poems belonging to the same type.
The first part of the book deals with the early heroic poetry and
traditions of the Teutonic peoples, more especially with those stories
which were the common property of various Teutonic peoples. It is
pointed out that these stories all relate to a period with definite
limits--a period for which a considerable amount of information is
available from external sources. The subjects discussed include
the distribution of the stories and the relationship between the
various versions of them, the antiquity of the earliest poems and the
conditions under which they were produced. Lastly, an attempt has been
made to estimate the significance of the various elements, historical,
mythical and fictitious, of which the stories are composed.
The second part deals with Greek heroic poetry and traditions. These
relate to a period for which little or no external evidence is
available; and consequently they present many problems, the bearings
of which can hardly be estimated without reference to the existence
of similar phenomena elsewhere. In general I have followed the same
plan as in the first part, and made use throughout of the results
obtained there. If some excuse is necessary for dealing with so well
worn a theme I may plead that, so far as my knowledge goes, it has not
hitherto been approached from this point of view.
In the third part attention has been called to the existence of a
number of somewhat striking characteristics common to the two groups
of poems and an attempt made to account for them. The conclusion to
which I have been brought is that the resemblances in the poems are
due primarily to resemblances in the ages to which they relate and to
which they ultimately owe their origin. The comparative study of heroic
poetry therefore involves the comparative study of 'Heroic Ages'; and
the problems which it presents are essentially problems of anthropology.
In this conclusion I am glad to find myself in agreement with Dr
Haddon, who suggested to me that a comparative study of this kind would
be a suitable subject for the Cambridge Archaeological and Ethnological
Series. I take this opportunity of thanking him for bringing the matter
before the Syndics of the University Press and for the interest which
he has kindly taken in the progress of the work.
Owing to the pressure of teaching and other duties a considerable time
has unfortunately elapsed since the earlier portions of the book were
printed. I would therefore respectfully call the reader's attention
to the list of Addenda at the end, where references will be found to
several important works which have appeared in the meantime.
In a work, such as this, which deals with records preserved in a number
of different languages, difficulties necessarily arise with regard to
the spelling of proper names. In the representation of Teutonic names
the system adopted in my previous books has in general been retained.
Any such system is of course open to objections, of the cogency of
which I am quite aware; and consequently I have not felt inclined to
carry out my scheme with rigid consistency. The same remarks apply to
the representation of Greek names--which will doubtless displease many
critics. South Slavonic names and words are given according to the
usual Croatian orthography.
I cannot attempt here to enumerate the various scholars to whose
writings I am indebted. It will be seen that they are many and that
much of what I have had to do is in the nature of criticism. One name
however, that of Professor Ridgeway, I cannot leave unmentioned, since
it is largely to his inspiring influence--by no means through his
writings alone--that my interest in these subjects is due.
It remains for me to record my obligations to a number of friends who
have generously responded to my requests for information or criticism
on various points. In particular I must mention Miss A. C. Paues, Mr
A. B. Cook, Dr W. H. R. Rivers, Mr S. A. Cook, Professor J. W. H.
Atkins, Professor A. Mawer, Mr E. H. Minns and Mr F. W. Green. Above
all I am indebted to Mr E. C. Quiggin and Mr F. G. M. Beck, who have
most kindly read through a considerable part of the book in proof
and several chapters even in manuscript. It is scarcely necessary to
add that in the sections dealing with Celtic history and poetry Mr
Quiggin's criticism has been of the greatest value to me. My thanks
are due, further, to my pupils, Mr C. A. Scutt, of Clare College, and
Mr Bruce Dickins, of Magdalene College, for similar kind services in
the proofs of the later chapters. From the staff of the University
Library--in particular I must mention Mr A. Rogers and Mr O. Johnson--I
have received the same unfailing and courteous attention as in the
past. Lastly, I have to thank the Syndics of the University Press for
undertaking the publication of the book and the staff for the efficient
and obliging way in which the printing and corrections have been
carried out.
H. M. C.
_December, 1911._

[1] Cf. Brandl in Paul's _Grundriss d. germ. Philol._², II pp. 1083
[2] Academy, 1896, I 137; cf. Brandl, _op. cit._, p. 1085.
[3] This remark applies more especially to the poems on Brunanburh and
Maldon in the later group.
[4] Saxo Poeta, who wrote about 890, speaks of _uulgaria carmina_ which
celebrated _Pippinos Carolos Hludowicos et Theodricos et Carlomannos
Hlothariosque_ (Mon. Germ., Script. I 268). But it is usually held that
these words are due to a mistaken inference from Einhard, whose work he
was using.

[7] The poems were not all composed in Iceland. Many of the earliest
doubtless came from Norway, others perhaps from the British Isles,
while others again are referred to Greenland.
[8] Called a dragon (_dreki_) in Völsunga Saga.
[9] Helreið Brynh. (str. 7 ff.) and the prose versions (Skaldsk.
41, Völs. S. 20). It is a much debated question whether the two are
identified also in Fáfnismál, str. 40 ff. In Grípisspá they seem
clearly to be separated.
[10] The death of Svanhildr is mentioned also in Sigurðarkviða II,
where it is attributed (as in the prose authorities) to the evil
counsel of a certain Bikki, an adviser of Iörmunrekr.
[11] Fornaldar Sögur Norðrlanda, I p. 391 ff.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[12] Except of course those which deal only with supernatural beings
[13] Quoted in the prose Edda (Skaldskaparmál, cap. 66).
[14] Theodosio XV et Valentiniano IV coss. (A.D. 435): _pax facta cum
Vandalis.... eodem tempore Gundicarium Burgundionum regem intra Gallias
habitantem Aetius bello obtriuit, pacemque ei supplicanti dedit, qua
non diu potitus est. siquidem illum Hunni cum populo atque stirpe sua
deleuerunt._
[15] The overthrow of Guthhere is ascribed to Attila by Paulus Diaconus
in his _Gesta episc. Mettensium_ (Mon. Germ., Scr. II p. 262), _Hist.
Misc._ XIV (Muratori, Scr. I p. 97); but he is a late authority. On the
other hand an anonymous Gaulish chronicle, which ends in the year 452,
attributes the whole of the Burgundian disasters to Aetius: _bellum
contra Burgundionum gentem memorabile exarsit quo uniuersa pene gens
cum rege per Aetium deleta_ (Mon. Germ., Chron. Min. I 660). But this
seems to be due to the confusion of two events which Prosper clearly
distinguishes (cf. Idatius, _Chron._, Theodosii ann. XII, XIII).
[16] Liber Legum Gundebati, cap. 3 (Mon. Germ., Leg., Vol. III p.
533): _si quos apud regiae memoriae auctores nostros, id est Gebicam,
Godomarem, Gislaharium, Gundaharium, patrem quoque nostrum et patruum,
liberos liberasue fuisse constiterit, in eadem libertate permaneant._
[17] This cycle is supposed to have been known in England at one time,
owing to the juxtaposition of the names Seafola (Saben) and Theodric in
Widsith, v. 115. Theodric, king of the Franks, is mentioned in the same
poem (v. 24).
[18] Cf. Berger de Xivrey, _Traditions Tératologiques_, p. 12.
[19] Einhardi Ann., 812 (Mon. Germ., Scr. I p. 199). Prof. Olrik
(_Nordisches Geistesleben_, p. 44) apparently rejects this
identification, as he places Haraldr Hilditönn not long after the time
of Hrólfr Kraki.
[20] The list makes no claim to completeness. Thus several of the
characters in Hervarar Saga (probably mentioned also in Widsith, v. 116
ff.) have been identified with historical persons of the fifth century.
But the evidence is far from satisfactory.
[21] _The Origin of the English Nation_, p. 134 f.
[22] But also with Theodric. This is a question to which we shall have
to refer later.
[23] _Venimus in illum locum ubi dudum Vidigoia, Gothorum fortissimus,
Sarmatum dolo occubuit_ (cf. also cap. 5).

line: the Edda therefore is no invention of an Icelandic or Norwegian poet,

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: but founded on a story which was current among the Romans within a

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: century after Attila's death. Indeed considering the circumstances it

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: is by no means unlikely that the story originated immediately after the

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: event.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: These examples will be sufficient to show that the subjects of many

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: of our poems are derived from stories which passed from one Teutonic

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: people to another and some of which were of great antiquity. Further,

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: it is a proof of the popularity of these stories that they were

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: preserved until comparatively late in the Middle Ages, in spite of

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the fact that they did not appeal to national interests. The question

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: how they were preserved and transmitted is one which we shall have to

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: discuss in the following chapters. We may note at once however that the

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: most obvious means of preservation, namely by means of writing, was

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: almost certainly not used to any great extent. Had that been the case

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the divergencies between the different versions of the stories would

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: be far less noticeable than they are. Even in the case of Waldhere,

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: which shows probably the least amount of variation, the Anglo-Saxon

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: fragments show a treatment of the subject totally different from that

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: which appears in Ekkehard's poem. Again, there is no evidence that

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the Roman alphabet was used in the North, except possibly by a few

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: foreigners here and there, before the end of the tenth century, while

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the Runic alphabet, though it had been known for many centuries, seems

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: not to have been employed for literary purposes until very late times.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: But, as we have already mentioned, some of the Edda poems date probably

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: from the ninth century, and the story of Heðinn and Högni is used by

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the poet Bragi who lived apparently in the early part of that century.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: On the Continent of course the case is somewhat different. We have

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: seen that Charlemagne did have a number of ancient poems written down;

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: but there is nothing to show that his collection had any permanent

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: influence. When the Quedlinburg annalist or his authority quotes the

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: heroic stories, perhaps some two centuries later, he refers not to any

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: written works but to songs formerly current among the country people.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: It is doubtless by oral tradition therefore, whether in verse or prose,

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: that the stories of the Heroic Age have mainly been preserved.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: There can be no question that a large number of similar stories

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: have perished. A glance through the catalogues of Widsith will show

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: many names which otherwise are entirely unknown to us, and also an

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: appreciable number which are not mentioned elsewhere in Anglo-Saxon

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: literature, though they figure in German and Scandinavian records. It

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: would scarcely be wise however to assume that all the stories of the

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Heroic Age were common Teutonic property. Thus we have no evidence

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: for the story of Waldhere in the North[32], while stories dealing

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: with Danish heroes seem to have been little known in Germany. The

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: latter observation deserves notice all the more in view of the obvious

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: popularity of such stories in England--a fact proved not merely by

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Beowulf and Finn, but still more by the prominence assigned to Danish

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: characters in Widsith.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: It will be convenient now to summarise briefly the results of our

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: discussion. We have seen that the scenes of the heroic stories are

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: distributed over most of the lands formerly occupied by the Teutonic

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: peoples. Norway and England however, as well as the distant kingdoms

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: of the Visigoths and Vandals, seem to lie outside the area. The heroes

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: also are drawn from many nations, though not in the proportion which

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: we should expect. Thus the Frankish nation, which ultimately became

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: dominant, is but poorly represented, while the most prominent places

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: are taken by peoples such as the Ostrogoths and Burgundians, which lost

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: their nationality in the course of the sixth century.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: We have further seen that a very large proportion of the characters of

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the heroic stories figure in the literature of two or more nations, and

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: that frequently the same stories are told of them. In the latter case

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: it is probable, indeed often practically certain, that the different

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: versions of the story are ultimately derived from a common narrative.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: On the other hand, where the same characters are known but only in

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: connection with different events, such derivation can be proved only

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: if it can be shown that the characters themselves are fictitious. This

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: remark applies especially to a number of characters common to Beowulf

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: and Scandinavian stories relating to Hrólfr Kraki and his times.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: It is fully in accord with these facts that the heroic poems are not

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: concerned at all--or at least only to a very slight degree--with local

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: or tribal interests. Their tone indeed may be described as in a sense

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: international, though with the restriction that characters and scenes

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: alike are drawn exclusively from within the Teutonic world.

Poem Title: SCENE AND NATIONALITY IN THE HEROIC STORIES.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[24] These poems do introduce Bavarian characters, such as the Markgraf
Rüdiger; but they are not found elsewhere in heroic poetry.
[25] In the prose piece _Frá dauði Sinfiötla_ (in the Older Edda)
Sigmundr is said to have held territories in the land of the Franks.
[26] Hence many scholars regard him as a Visigoth.
[27] Tyrol is the scene of several of Dietrich's and Wolfdietrich's
adventures; but generally it is the southern (Italian) part of that
country.
[28] The poem on the battle of Maldon approximates much more closely
than any other of this age to the spirit of the old poetry.
[29] The victories over the Saxons and Danes described in the
Nibelungenlied and the Tháttr af Nornagesti have little in common and
are scarcely to be regarded as an essential feature in the story of
Sigurðr.
[30] _Anastasius annos_ XXVII.... _Ermanrici regis Gothorum a
fratribus Hemido et Serilo et Adaccaro, quorum patrem interfecerat,
amputatis manibus et pedibus turpiter, ut dignus erat, occisio_ (Mon.
Germ., Scr. III p. 31).
[31] Ind. VII. Aetio et Studio coss. (A.D. 454): _Attila rex Hunnorum
Europae orbator prouinciae noctu mulieris manu cultroque confoditur.
quidam uero sanguinis reiectione necatum perhibent._
[32] Excluding of course Thiðreks S. af Bern.
CHAPTER IV.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In an earlier chapter (p. 3) it was mentioned that the English heroic

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: poems are usually ascribed to the seventh or eighth centuries. We

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: must now try to see whether any means are to be found of dating their

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: composition more precisely.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Unfortunately very few references to the poems or their subjects occur

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in works which can be dated with anything like certainty. The most

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: important is contained in a letter from Alcuin to Hygebald, bishop of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Lindisfarne, written in the year 797: "When priests dine together let

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the words of God be read. It is fitting on such occasions to listen

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: to a reader, not to a harpist, to the discourses of the fathers,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: not to the poems of the heathen. What has Ingeld to do with Christ?

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Strait is the house; it will not be able to hold them both. The king

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of heaven will have no part with so-called kings who are heathen and

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: damned; for the one king reigns eternally in heaven, the other, the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: heathen, is damned and groans in hell. In your houses the voices of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: those who read should be heard, not a rabble of those who make merry

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in the streets[33]." From this passage it is clear that at the end of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the eighth century there were current in Northumbria certain poems,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: probably well known poems, dealing with a heathen king named Ingeld,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: whom we need not hesitate to identify with Ingeld the son of Froda,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: who figures in Beowulf. Of course it is not at all likely that the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: reference is to Beowulf itself, for the part played by Ingeld in that

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: poem is insignificant.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Acquaintance with the subjects of the heroic poems is shown also by a

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: mistake in the Historia Brittonum, 31, which dates probably from about

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the same period. This passage contains a genealogy, tracing the descent

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of Hengest and Horsa from Woden and of Woden from Geat. The latter part

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is known also from many other texts, in which it regularly runs as

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: follows: _Woden Frealafing, Frealaf Frithuwulfing, Frithuwulf Finning,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Finn Godwulfing, Godwulf Geating_. In the Historia Brittonum however

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in place of _Finn Godwulfing_ we find _Finn qui fuit Folcwald_--which

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is clearly due to confusion with Finn the son of Folcwalda (_Finn

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Folcwalding_), a Frisian king mentioned in Beowulf and Widsith, as well

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: as in the fragment which bears his name.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Further evidence is afforded by names of persons and places. There

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: can be no doubt that even in the seventh century it was customary to

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: take the names of famous men of the past or present. Danihel, bishop

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of Winchester (d. 745), and Iohannes, bishop of Hexham (d. 721), are

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: instances which no one will dispute. In the Durham Liber Vitae we meet

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: with the names Aethan and Cundigeorn. It must not be assumed that

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: persons bearing such names were necessarily of Celtic blood. Indeed the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: spelling suggests rather that they were Englishmen called after Aidan

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and Kentigern. Deusdedit, archbishop of Canterbury (655-664), doubtless

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: derived his name from Pope Deusdedit (615-618), while the West Saxon

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: king Ceadwalla (685-688) was in all probability called after the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: British king of the same name, who died in 642. It is extremely likely

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that Hlothhere, king of Kent (673-685), obtained his name from one of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Frankish kings, Lothair II (584-628) or Lothair III (656-670), for

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the element _hloth-_ is not used elsewhere in Anglo-Saxon names. Even

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in the sixth century we hear of English princes who seem to be called

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: after Frankish or Gothic kings of the same period. Thus Tytla, the name

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of the father of the East Anglian king Redwald, is probably taken from

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Gothic king Totila; it is not of an English type. Two sons of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Northumbrian king Ida were called Theodric and Aethelric, perhaps

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: after the Gothic king Theodric and his successor Athalaric. As the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: element _theod-_ is somewhat rare in England, it is not unlikely that

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Northumbrian prince Theodbald, a son of Aethelric, derived his name

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: from the Frankish king Theodbald.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: The occurrence of such names as Widsith and Beowulf (_Biuulf_) in the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Liber Vitae shows that names were taken not only from contemporary

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: persons and from books but also from native poems and traditions.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Indeed researches which have been made in this direction have

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: demonstrated that names of the latter type were extremely popular. But

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: it has not been sufficiently pointed out that such names occur most

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: frequently in the earliest times and gradually become more rare--a fact

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which is of considerable importance for our purpose. The total number

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of personal names found in the five poems Beowulf, Finn, Waldhere,

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Widsith and Deor is 132[34], and of these altogether 57 recur as names

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of persons mentioned in English historical documents. Over forty of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: these names belonged to persons who appear to have lived, or at any

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: rate to have been born, before the end of the seventh century[35],

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: while at least thirteen of them are unknown after the same period. To

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the latter class belong the important names Widsith and Beowulf.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In local nomenclature it is possible to trace at least 51 of the 132

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: names mentioned above. In some cases these names may have been taken

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: direct from the story, e.g. when we find in Kent two localities close

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: together called _Hokes clif_ and _Hengstes earas_ (Birch, _Cart.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Sax._, III 1000). A similar case, very frequently cited[36], is that

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of _Beowanhammes hecgan_ and _Grendeles mere_ in Wiltshire (_ib._ II

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: 677), though neither of these names is included in our list. But in the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: majority of cases it is more probable that the place-name is taken in

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the first instance from that of a previous landowner, and consequently

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that the connection with the story is only secondary. Hence it is

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: important to notice that out of the 51 place-names no less than 19

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: contain names which are not borne by persons in historical documents.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: The explanation of this lies doubtless in the fact that the place-names

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: for the most part became fixed at a very early period, and consequently

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that they exhibit an earlier stratum of personal nomenclature.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: If we add the place-names to the personal names the total number of

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: heroic names found in England in historical documents seems to be

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: 76. Out of this number only seven apparently are limited to persons

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: born after the end of the seventh century, and of these again almost

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: all occur in the course of the eighth century. These statistics show

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: clearly that such names were most popular during the sixth and seventh

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: centuries, especially if we bear in mind that the materials for this

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: period are incomparably less than those for the following three

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: centuries. Hence, if we are justified in drawing any conclusions from

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: nomenclature, the popularity of the heroic stories was distinctly on

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the wane in Alcuin's time.

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: The argument from nomenclature holds good of course only for showing

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the popularity of the stories; it cannot prove the existence of the

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: poems which we now possess. In one case however we may probably make an

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: exception. The name _Widsith_ is obviously fictitious[37] and based on

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the travels with which the minstrel is credited. The introduction, in

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which alone the name occurs, is in all probability a later composition

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: than the rest of the poem[38] and designed to explain what follows. It

Poem Title: THE ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is of importance therefore to note that, if we may judge from the place

Christ (II) 28:3, Elene 66:9, Guthlac (A) 42:6, Dream of the Cross
10:5, Exodus 10:14, Beowulf 13:65; see Brandl, _S.-B. d. Akad. der
Wiss. zu Berlin_, 1905, p. 718 f.
[41] Cf. Brandl, _l.c._ (p. 721 ff.).
[42] Hist. Eccl., IV 24: _canebat autem de creatione mundi et origine
humani generis et tota genesis historia, de egressu Israel ex Aegypto
et ingressu in terram repromissionis, de aliis plurimis sacrae
scripturae historiis, de incarnatione dominica, passione, resurrectione
et ascensione in caelum, de Spiritus Sancti aduentu et apostolorum
doctrina. item de terrore futuri iudicii et horrore poenae gehennalis
ac dulcedine regni caelestis multa carmina faciebat; sed et perplura de
beneficiis et iudiciis diuinis, etc._ Prof. Brandl (_Grundr._, II 1028)
holds that the reference is to lyric poems throughout. But is this
interpretation really necessary?
[43] On this date see Note II.
[44] For a brief discussion of this question see Note III.
[45] A few examples are given in the following chapter.
[50] It is perhaps worth noting that in v. 2186 the expression _dryhten
wereda_ is used of Hygelac. Elsewhere in Anglo-Saxon poetry this phrase
is applied only to the Deity.
[51] Clark Hall, _Beowulf_, p. xxviii.
[52] If there is Celtic influence at all it is more probably Welsh.
[53] Cf. p. 46, note, where the passage is quoted in full.
[54] The amount of freedom differs of course greatly from case to case
(cf. Note IV, p. 101 ff.); but it is only in communities which have
elaborated the art of minstrelsy to a very high degree that the form of
words can become absolutely stereotyped.
[56] _Quellen und Forschungen_, LXII (1888); summarised p. 242 ff.
[57] _The Origin of the English Nation_, p. 93, note.
[58] The references quoted on p. 41 ff. preclude the possibility that
these stories were first acquired from the Danes, when the latter again
became known in this country about the close of the eighth century.
[59] A different view is taken by Schücking, _Beowulfs Rückkehr_
(Studien zur engl. Philologie, XXI), p. 65 ff.
[60] We may refer especially to the account of Attila's funeral given
by Jordanes, cap. 49 (from Priscus).
[61] Apart from certain expressions the general tone of these speeches,
especially the last words of all (v. 2813 ff.), is scarcely Christian;
but they contain nothing which is obviously opposed to Christian
doctrine.
[62] E.g. in the imprecation, v. 3069 ff. The imprecatory formulae of
charters can scarcely be regarded as analogous.
[63] Cf. Brandl, _op. cit._, p. 1003.
[64] The same idea is frequently expressed in the Homeric poems, e.g.
Il. VII 79 f., XXII 342 f., XXIII 75 f., XXIV 37 f., Od. XI 71 ff., etc.
[65] This date does not depend in any way on the question where the
poem originated. Cremation may possibly have lingered in Northumbria
longer than elsewhere; but that kingdom seems to have become entirely
Christian between 626 and 642.
[66] E.g. possibly some of the elegiac passages (e.g. vv. 2236-2270,
2450-2464), which show a certain resemblance to such poems as the Ruin
and the Wanderer.
[67] The name _Hegelinge_ in Kûdrûn is probably a corruption of
_Hetelinge_ (i.e. _Heodeningas_).
[68] Presumably including vv. 88-108; but I am not prepared to suggest
an elaborate analysis of the poem.
[69] These lists are perhaps derived in part from mnemonic
catalogues--'inventories' of the stories known to the minstrels who
composed them. Metrical catalogues of this kind are said to be in use
among Servian minstrels at the present day; cf. Krauss, _Slavische
Volkforschungen_, p. 186 ff., where a specimen is given.
[70] Waldhere, Deor and Widsith all contain 'Christian' passages,
like Beowulf. The interpolations in Widsith (e.g. vv. 15 f., 82 ff.)
appear to have been made by some one who possessed a certain amount of
erudition; but there is no need to attribute them to a different period.
[71] Cf. Olrik, _Kilderne til Sakses Oldhistorie_, p. 132.
[72] The name appears to have been quite common in the North during the
Viking Age; yet the apparent absence of umlaut suggests derivation from
a (Frisian?) form corresponding to the Ang.-Sax. _Aetla_ (cf. _Aecci_,
_Aeddi_ beside _Acca_, _Adda_).
[73] In contrast (e.g.) with _Kûdrûn_, which clearly shows its foreign
origin (cf. p. 34).
[74] Such names may have been current before, though their frequent
occurrence is no proof of this and may be due to the popularity of the
heroic poems. It is perhaps worth noting that alliteration is shown by
certain names which are generally believed to have been introduced into
the story in Norway or Iceland, e.g. _Oddrún_, _Erpr_, _Eitill_ with
_Atli_, _Giaflaug_, _Gullrönd_ (_Guðrún_?) with _Giuki_ and _Gunnarr_.
If we may judge from the genealogies in Landnámabók and elsewhere the
principle of alliteration seems to have been generally given up in
family names before the ninth century.
[75] _The Cult of Othin_, p. 51 f.
[76] Cf. Bugge, _Beiträge_, XII 45 ff.
[77] Cf. Sievers, _Ges. d. Wiss. zu Leipzig, Ber._ 1895, p. 180 ff.
[78] _Kilderne til Sakses Oldhistorie_, pp. 18 ff., 132.
[79] _The Origin of the English Nation_, p. 118 ff.
[80] _Item barbara et antiquissima carmina, quibus ueterum regum actus
et bella canebantur, scripsit memoriaeque mandauit_ (Vita Caroli Magni,
[81] Cassiodorus (_Var._ VIII 9) states that the Gothic king
Gensimundus, who according to Jordanes (cap. 48) reigned shortly
after Eormenric's death, was widely celebrated in poetry (_toto orbe
cantabilis_); but his name is preserved only in Gothic records.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[95] _Transactions of the Cambridge Philological Society_, Vol. IV,
Part II. The page-references are to the figures in the outer corners.
[96] _Nachrichten von der Königl. Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu
Göttingen_, 1906, pp. 251-277.
[97] Prof. Morsbach's paper raises a number of questions besides those
mentioned above. But I am obliged here to confine my attention to those
which have a bearing on the dating of Beowulf.
[98] The application of this term to the Epinal and Erfurt glossaries
(or the archetype) seems to me to be open to grave objection.
[99] If I have interpreted his meaning correctly. But I admit that I
have had great difficulty in understanding the argument in paragraph 5
of p. 263 (especially the "mit _-h-_" of line 12).
[100] Prof. Morsbach seems to regard Kentish as exceptional in its
treatment of intervocalic _h_, rather than in that of postconsonantal
_h_. I am not quite clear as to his reason for this.
[101] Cf. _Studies in Old English_, p. 240.
[102] This text represents a more primitive type of glossary than the
others and, though it is not an ancestor of theirs, it has without
doubt used a considerable number of the same glosses (especially in
Sweet's § XLV) which were incorporated in their archetype.
[103] The form _scanomodu_ on the solidus need not be taken into
account. It is improbable that coins of this type were minted after the
sixth century.
[104] Prof. Morsbach further argues that even if my interpretation of
_unneg_ was correct it would prove nothing, since _-u_ was probably
lost after a long 'nebentonig' syllable earlier than after a long
'haupttonig' syllable. But neither the _-gar_ of the Bewcastle
inscription (cf. p. 70) nor the _felt_ of the East Saxon charter can be
admitted as evidence for this hypothesis.
[105] In spite of what is said by Prof. Morsbach (p. 264 f.) these
forms are scarcely intelligible unless _h_ was already lost.
[106] E.g. perhaps _flod u(p)ahof_.
[107] The place-name _Wihtgarabyrg_ in the Saxon Chronicle, ann. 530
(B, C), 544 (A, B, C) is more probably to be regarded as a corruption
of _Wihtwara-_ through the influence of the personal name _Wihtgar_.
[108] Prof. Morsbach's explanation is that _felt_ here is a long
nebentonig syllable. But we have no evidence that the influence of
'sentence-accent' made itself felt in this way.
[109] Prof. Morsbach would assign the monument to the time of Aldfrith,
who reigned 685-705 (not 725, a printer's error in Vietor's book).
[110] In his own narrative of course he often uses forms which must
have been antiquated in his time (e.g. _Vurtigerno_, _Aeduini_,
_Aeodbaldo_) and also foreign forms in the names of persons of
Continental origin (e.g. _Agilberctus_). But it may safely be assumed
that all these cases are derived from earlier documents.
[111] I.e. Oswiu (Oswald); cf. _Baduuini_, i.e. Baduwini. I have not
taken account of the possibility that _-uiu_ originally contained
an _-h-_. If that could be proved the present discussion would be
practically superfluous.
[112] Cf. my Studies, p. 247. It will be seen that the number of cases
in which M, B and C agree in _f_ (for _ƀ_) is very small.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[113] The case of King Aldfrith shows that educated laymen were not
entirely unknown; but it is extremely unlikely that they were common.
In one charter (Birch, 99) Wihtred, king of Kent, is made to say:
_signum sanctae crucis pro ignorantia litterarum expressi_. This
document exists only in a late copy; but at all events it suggests that
the practice of making the cross, instead of signing, was due to a
widespread inability to write.
[114] I confess that I am strongly inclined to suspect that anyone
imbued with Latin learning would have lacked not only the inclination
but also the ability to compose such a poem as Beowulf. This however is
an opinion which could only be substantiated by a wider knowledge of
the history of poetry in various parts of the world than I can make any
claim to possess.
[115] _Grundriss d. germ. Philol._, II 1008.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: claim to that title, whatever its original length may have been. The

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: extant portion contains nine speeches, by seven different persons.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Twenty-two warriors in the English army are mentioned by name, and in

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: about a dozen cases the names of their fathers or other relatives are

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: also given. The poem differs from the heroic type in the fact that it

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: does not record the name of a single person among the enemy; but that

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: need not prevent us from regarding it as an epic. Yet there can be no

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: reasonable doubt that it was composed within a few years, possibly even

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: months, of the battle[143].

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: It is likely enough that the author of this poem was well acquainted

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: with heroic poetry and that his treatment of the subject was affected

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: thereby. But is that any objection to supposing that poems of this type

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: may have been composed within the Heroic Age itself? We have no reason

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: whatever for denying that this age was capable of such compositions.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Indeed there is one piece of evidence which points very much to the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: contrary.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: This is a passage which occurs in Procopius' History of the Gothic

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: War (IV 20). After describing the embassy sent to Justinian by the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Utiguri in the year 551, the author goes on to state that 'about this

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: time' hostilities broke out between the nation of the Warni and the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Angli (Ἀγγίλοι) who inhabit the island of Britain (Βριττία). Not long

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: before the Warni had been ruled by a king named Hermegisklos who,

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: being anxious to establish his throne on a secure foundation, sought

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: and obtained in marriage a sister of Theodberht, king of the Franks.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: By a previous wife he had an only son named Radiger, who at this time

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: was betrothed to a sister of the king of the Angli and had paid her a

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: large sum of money in furtherance of his suit[144]. One day, when the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: king was riding in a certain place with the chief men of his nation, he

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: saw a bird sitting on a tree and croaking loudly. Now, whether it was

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: that he really understood what the bird said, or whether he had some

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: other source of information but pretended that the bird was uttering a

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: prophecy which he understood--at all events he declared on the spot to

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: his companions that he would die forty days later, for this had been

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: clearly foretold to him by the bird[145]. Thereupon he gives advice

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: as to what should be done after his death, namely that Radiger should

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: marry his widow, in accordance with national custom, and dissolve

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: his engagement with the English princess. On the fortieth day the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: king died, and Radiger proceeds to carry out his injunctions. But the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: princess, infuriated at his conduct, gathers together a fleet of four

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: hundred vessels and invades the land of the Warni with 100,000 men.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Radiger's army is completely defeated, and he takes refuge in a dense

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: forest. The princess insists on his being taken alive at all costs, and

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: eventually he is captured and brought before her. He expects to be put

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: to death, but after explaining the cause of his action, he is pardoned

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: on condition that he returns to his former engagement.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: This story contains a number of features, such as the prophecy of the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: bird, the payment of the 'bride-fee' and Radiger's marriage with his

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: stepmother, which show clearly that it was derived from someone who

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: was well acquainted with the peoples of northern Europe. There is no

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: ground for disputing that it has a historical basis; but at the same

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: time it is obviously much more than a mere record of facts. Apart from

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: the incident of the bird and the gross exaggeration apparent in certain

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: details[146], the pictorial character of the narrative, especially

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: in its earlier part, indicates a close affinity with heroic poetry.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Un-heroic features are not wanting--the introduction of nameless

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: persons and the political reflections of Irmingisl--but they may with

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: probability be attributed to Procopius himself. I do not mean to

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: suggest that his source of information was an epic poem, but I do think

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: that the intellectual atmosphere which could produce such a story must

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: have been exactly of the kind most favourable to the growth of such

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: compositions.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Procopius, as we have seen, places this war in or about the year 551,

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: and we can certainly understand the course of events more easily if

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: it took place after Theodberht's death (A.D. 548). Therefore, since

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Procopius' work appears to have been written within the next seven or

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: eight years, the story had had little time to develop before it came

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: to his ears. On the other hand we must remember that it refers to a

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: distant region--a fact I think not without significance for the history

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: of contemporary narrative poetry. To persons who had themselves taken

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: part in the events poems like that on the battle of Brunanburh would

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: appeal much more strongly than purely narrative pieces. It is for

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: persons who were either ignorant of the events or knew them only by

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: hearsay that the latter would seem to be primarily intended.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: In this discussion we have taken no account of the heroic poems of the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Edda. There can be little doubt that these poems must be assigned to

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: Stage IV of our scheme; for though some of them are probably three or

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: four centuries older than the German poems of this class, they bear

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: fairly obvious marks of the disintegrating process which seems to

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: characterise popular poetry[147]. It may be asked how such an opinion

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: is compatible with the view that the story of Sigurðr was derived

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: from the Continent during the seventh century (cf. p. 59). The true

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: explanation is, I believe, that heroic poetry passed through Stage III

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: after it became known in Norway.

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: We noted in an earlier chapter (pp. 30, 33) that Norway plays no part

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: in stories of the Heroic Age. On the other hand it has what we may call

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: a Heroic Age of its own--namely the Viking Age. We have no poems--and

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: few stories of any kind--dealing with persons of Norwegian nationality

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: who lived before that period. The remoteness, poverty and mountainous

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: nature of the country doubtless retarded its development, not only

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: politically but also in the cultivation of poetry. The strophic

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: character of all Norse poetry is generally held to point to a choric

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: origin, and it may very well be that this primitive type of poetry

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: was the only one used in Norway when the heroic stories first became

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: known there. Possibly it was to Frisian and Danish minstrels that the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: change was due[148]. But the conditions suitable for a flourishing

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: court-poetry, like that of the Heroic Age, scarcely existed before the

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: last years of the eighth century, when Norwegian princes had begun to

Poem Title: THE POETRY AND MINSTRELSY OF EARLY TIMES.
line: enrich themselves with maritime enterprises.

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: The nearest modern analogy, at least in Europe, to the types of poetry

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: which we have been discussing is probably to be found among the various

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: peoples of Serbo-Croatian nationality. As an example we may take the

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: poetry current among the Mohammedan population of Bosnia[149]. Since

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: the occupation of that province a large number of narrative poems have

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: been collected and published, though only a few are as yet accessible

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: in translations. These poems afford an interesting illustration of our

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: subject, not only because they deal with similar themes--heroism in

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: battle, single combats, love and revenge--and often in quite as full

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: detail, but also since the events with which they are concerned and

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: the conditions they reflect belong to a well-marked historical period,

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: which we may regard as a kind of Heroic Age. The period in question

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: embraces the greater part of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries,

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: more especially the latter, a time when the Turkish Empire was at the

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: height of its power, and when its armies were frequently engaged in

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: hostilities with the Austrians in Hungary and Croatia. Many of the

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: characters mentioned in the poems are well known historical persons.

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: But beyond all this the value of the illustration lies largely in the

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: fact that we have here what may be called a living heroic poetry,

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: such as we hear of among the Teutonic peoples only through occasional

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: notices in ancient records. As among the latter it is customary for the

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: minstrel (_pivač_, dial. for _pjevač_) to accompany his recitation on a

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: musical instrument, the _tambura_, a kind of guitar with only two metal

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: strings. Among the Christian population the _gusle_, a primitive type

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: of fiddle, is in use.

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: The poems vary greatly in length. Out of 320 pieces collected by

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: Dr Marjanović thirty contained less than 100 verses, while fifteen

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: exceeded 2000, the longest of all amounting to over 4000. The average

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: length of the pieces described as epic is given at 873 verses; a

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: hundred and three vary from 600 to 1000, and sixty-two from 1000 to

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: 1500. These figures are especially important in view of their bearing

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: on certain prevalent ideas as to the limits of oral poetry. It is to be

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: observed that the ordinary Servian metre is decasyllabic, the verse not

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: being appreciably shorter than the average Teutonic alliterative verse.

Poem Title: NOTE IV. ON THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE SLAVONIC PEOPLES.
line: The minstrel begins his recitation quite slowly, but after about a

line: FOOTNOTES:
[149] The first part of this note is mainly derived from an interesting
paper by Prof. M. Murko in the _Zeitschrift des Vereins für Volkskunde_
(Berlin), 1909, p. 13 ff., to which the reader is referred for further
information and authorities. The collections of poems published by
Marjanović and Hörmann have not been accessible to me.
[150] Some interesting remarks relating to the prevalence of
minstrelsy--apparently among the Christian population--during the
eighteenth century are to be found in Fortis' _Travels into Dalmatia_
(London, 1778). "A Morlacco travels along the desert mountains singing,
especially in the night time, the actions of ancient _Slavi_ kings and
barons or some tragic event.... Although the Morlacchi usually sing
their ancient songs, yet other poetry is not altogether extinguished
among them; and their musicians, after singing an ancient piece,
accompanied with the _guzla_, sometimes finish it with some extempore
verses, in praise of the personage by whom they are employed" (_ib._,
[151] The following observations are based on the poems published in
Krauss' _Slavische Volkforschungen_.
[152] Thus in a number of poems the Beg Ljubović appears as the
representative of Hercegovina.
[153] Especially several of those dealing with the battle of Kossovo
(1389), to which we shall have to refer in a later note.
[154] There are references to the existence of heroic poetry in the
neighbourhood of Spalato and Sebenico as far back as the sixteenth
century; cf. Murko, _Arch. f. slav. Philol._, XXVIII 378. A much
earlier reference has been traced in Nicephorus Gregoras' account
(_Hist. Byz._, VIII 14) of his mission to the court of Stephan Uroš
in the year 1326, where it is stated of his followers: φωναῖς ἐχρῶντο
καὶ μέλεσι τραγικοῖς· ᾖδον δ' ἄρα κλέα ἀνδρῶν ὧν οἷον κλέος ἀκούομεν
οὐδέ τοι ἴδμεν. But it is extremely doubtful whether these persons were
Servians.
[155] In the middle of the sixteenth century the Slovenians of Tolmino
used to sing "di Mattia re d' Ungheria e di altri celebri personaggi di
quella nazione" (Murko, _Zeitschr. d. Vereins f. Volksk._, 1909, p. 14,
note). Matthias Hunyadi died in 1490.
[156] Wiener, _Anthology of Russian Literature_, I p. 84.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: many difficulties, both historical and linguistic, that it cannot be

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: approached with safety except by an expert. We shall have to confine

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: our attention therefore to the heroic poetry of the Cymry.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Even here the difficulties to be encountered are sufficiently serious.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Yet it is fairly clear that many of these poems deal with events which

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: are referred by the chronicles to the sixth century and the first half

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of the seventh. We may note especially four groups of poems: (1) a few

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: concerned with the exploits of Arthur and his heroes; (2) a somewhat

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: larger number referring to princes named Gwallawg, Urien and Rhydderch;

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: (3) certain poems dealing with _Gododin_ and _Catraeth_; (4) a few

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: elegy over Cynddylan, which seem to refer to the same period, though

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: they cannot be classed under any of these headings. A number of the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: above poems, especially those included in the second and third groups,

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: There is no doubt that Cadwallon is the well known Welsh king who

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: overthrew the Northumbrian king Edwin in 633 and was himself destroyed

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: also to have a historical basis. In the Historia Brittonum (Harleian

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: his successors, Frithuwald and Hussa. Urbgen is said to have besieged

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
