Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: perished eventually through the jealousy of Morcant. In another passage

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: (§ 62) we hear of _Neirin et Taliessin_ among other poets who composed

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: British poetry in the time of a king named Dutigirn[157], who is made

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: contemporary with Ida, the father of Theodric. The origin of these

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: entries is unfortunately obscure. They are incorporated with an English

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: genealogical document, dating apparently from the end of the eighth

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: century; but they may quite possibly be derived from earlier sources.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: In any case they cannot well be later than the first quarter of the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: ninth century.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: All the four kings mentioned in § 63 are known to us also from

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: genealogies of the tenth century. But one of them, Riderch Hen, is

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: named in Adamnan's Life of St Columba, which is of course altogether

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: independent of Welsh tradition. It is there stated (I 15[158]) that

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Rodercus, king of Dumbarton, consulted St Columba as to his fate and

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: received the answer that he would die a peaceful death in his house--a

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: prophecy which was subsequently fulfilled. As St Columba died probably

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: in 597, the date given for Riderch Hen agrees well enough with what is

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: stated in the Historia Brittonum; for according to the most trustworthy

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: records Theodric and his two immediate successors reigned from about

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: 572 to 592 or 593. We have no ground for doubting that the references

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: to Urbgen and the rest are based on equally good tradition.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: For the characters mentioned in the Gododin poems no such evidence is

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: available. The poems themselves however contain references to the death

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of _Dyvynwal Vrych_--doubtless the Dalriadic king Domnall Brecc, who

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: according to the Irish annals was killed by the Britons three years

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: after the fall of Oswald, i.e. about the year 645. Unfortunately it

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: is not made clear in what relationship this event stands to the main

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: action of the poems[159]. The few identifications which can be made

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: from the genealogies seem to be compatible with a date somewhere about

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: this time.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: There can scarcely be any doubt that we are justified in regarding

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the period covered by the poems as a kind of Heroic Age. The story of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Arthur was the one most elaborated in later times--a process which

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: must have begun before the ninth century, when it was incorporated in

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the Historia Brittonum (§ 56). How much historical truth this story

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: contains we do not know, though the chronicles refer Arthur to the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: early part of the sixth century, i.e. the beginning of our period. To

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: a certain extent however the other stories have experienced the same

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: process; for, apart from the question when the poems under discussion

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: were composed, there are others of undoubtedly later date, such as the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Englynion y Beddau, in which the same heroes are mentioned. Moreover it

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: must not be assumed that these were the only persons of the same period

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: whose praises were celebrated in poetry. Maelgwn, king of Gwynedd, who

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: died about 548, figures prominently in traditions of later times, and

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: it is likely enough that the beginnings of these stories were due to a

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: similar cause. On the other hand there is apparently no evidence for

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the composition of poems dealing with the exploits of princes who lived

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: in the latter part of the seventh century or for several centuries

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: later.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: As to the origin of the poems discussed above we have no evidence which

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: can be called conclusive. Some of the poems themselves claim to be the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: work of the poets Aneirin and Taliessin. At the present time however

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: it seems to be generally held[160] that they are scholastic products

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of a later age, based upon chronicles and composed with the intention

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of glorifying the ancestry of some distinguished Welsh families. In

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: support of this view it is contended that the language of the poems

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: cannot possibly represent the form of Welsh spoken in the sixth or

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: seventh centuries. But this argument is scarcely decisive; for it

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: is clear that parts of the poems have undergone a certain amount of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: modernisation, and it is by no means incredible that the same process

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: may have been in operation for centuries. I find it difficult to

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: believe that in order to celebrate the ancestry of certain families

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: poems would be composed recording an action which is represented as an

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: overwhelming disaster for the British forces, such as that described in

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the Gododin poems. And can it really be proved that many of the heroes

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: celebrated in these poems were claimed as ancestors by families in

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Wales?

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: At all events it is clear that the author of the entries in the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Historia Brittonum knew of ancient British poets. _Neirin_ and

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: _Taliessin_ are only two out of five names recorded by him, the rest

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: apparently being altogether unknown from other sources[161]. It is

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: true that he places all these persons about a generation before Urien

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: and Rhydderch Hen, but chronological accuracy is hardly to be expected

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: in references to such a remote period. Certainly we should note that

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the last British king mentioned in these entries is a certain Cadafael

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: (_Catgabail Catguommed_), who is said to have escaped alone from the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: battle in which Penda was killed (A.D. 655). The wording of this

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: passage (§ 65) seems rather to suggest acquaintance with a poem on the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: subject.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: We have seen now that the persons and events celebrated in the poems

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: belong to a period extending roughly from 500 to 650 and that there

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: are ancient records of famous British poets, who are referred to

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the earlier part of this period and of whom two are traditionally

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: associated with the poems. Next we must notice that the poems

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: themselves, even in the corrupt and often unintelligible form in

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: which they are preserved, plainly show all the marks of Stage I of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: our scheme. Their characteristics are those of court-poetry, but they

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: never attain to true narrative. For analogies to the poems which deal

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: with Urien we can hardly do better than turn to the court-poetry of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the Viking Age (cf. pp. 15 f., 91); for the Gododin poems perhaps the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: best parallels are to be found in the Battle of Maldon and the Story

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of Igor's Expedition, though in both the latter the narrative element

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: is much more fully developed. Taking all the evidence into account,

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: it seems to me that the choice lies between two alternatives: either

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: the poems really are works of Stage I, which have survived from the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Heroic Age itself, or they are exceedingly clever imitations of such

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: works, composed at a time when the latter were still in existence.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: The decision between these two alternatives must of course be left to

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: experts. In the meantime we shall be ready to admit that the poems are

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: extremely corrupt, and that in some cases perhaps we have nothing more

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: than disjecta membra of earlier pieces. But until conclusive evidence

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: is brought forward it seems to me highly improbable that the original

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: poems have been entirely lost[162].

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: The history of Cumbrian heroic poetry is easily intelligible when

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: taken in connection with the national history. It is probable enough

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: that on the withdrawal of the legions large portions of the country

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: were occupied by northern Britons from beyond the Wall--who are

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: represented in tradition by Cunedda and his sons[163]. These were

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: doubtless affected by Roman influence to a very much less degree

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: than the inhabitants of the province; and the growth of heroic poetry

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: during the sixth century may be satisfactorily accounted for by the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: wealth and prosperity which would naturally accrue to their princely

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: families during the early days of their dominion. It was probably not

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: until the time of Aethelfrith that their power was really broken.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: But the following half century was a most disastrous period, ending

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: in the permanent obliteration of their nationality--in a political

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: sense--throughout the whole region between the Dee and the Clyde. Any

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: records which survived must owe their preservation, ultimately at

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: least, to refugees who escaped into the Welsh highlands.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Now we can see why so many place-names (Reged, Catraeth and dozens of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: others) are incapable of identification. But further, the conditions in

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Wales, the poorest and probably the most backward part of the province,

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: were doubtless highly unfavourable to the development of heroic poetry.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Under such conditions we should expect that narrative poems would

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: rapidly disintegrate into the semblance of folk-tales; and it may be

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: that here we have the explanation of the medieval stories of Arthur. At

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: all events they show a certain resemblance to the Russian stories of

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: Vladimir and his heroes. But Arthur, as we have seen, belongs to the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: beginning of the Heroic Age. We have no evidence for the composition

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: of poems, which can properly be called narrative, dealing with the

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: later heroes. Here the original type of poem seems to have become

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: stereotyped--presumably because conditions favourable to development

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: were no longer present. The only marvel is that so much has been

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.
line: preserved.

Poem Title: NOTE V. THE HEROIC POETRY OF THE CELTIC PEOPLES.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[157] _Tunc Dutigirn in illo tempore fortiter dimicabat contra gentem
Anglorum, tunc Talhaern Tataguen in poemate claruit, et Neirin et
Taliessin et Bluchbard et Cian, qui uocatur Gueinth Guaut, simul uno
tempore in poemate Britannico claruerunt._
[158] _De rege Roderco, filio Tothail, qui in Petra Cloithe regnauit._
[159] It is possibly worth noting that the Irish annals record a battle
between Oswio and the Britons in the same year as Domnall Brecc's
death; cf. Skene, _Chronicles of the Picts and Scots_, pp. 70, 348.
[160] This view is favoured by Prof. Anwyl in his _Prolegomena to the
Study of Old Welsh Poetry_ (Trans. of the Hon. Soc. of Cymmrodorion,
[161] It has been suggested that _Bluchbard_ (cf. p. 106, note) may be
a corruption of the name _Llywarch_. Certainly the form _Neirin_ (which
is thought to be due to a misunderstanding of _aneirin_ as _et neirin_)
seems to show that the scribe himself had no knowledge of Aneirin.
[162] The question of the antiquity of the poems must of course be
distinguished from that of their authorship. If they are, even in part,
the work of Taliessin and Aneirin, we must conclude that these poets
are wrongly dated in the Historia Brittonum.
[163] In dealing with such traditions it is essential to remember that
our authorities date from times when (apart from Strathclyde) the Cymry
had long been confined to Wales and that they represent the point of
view of writers living in Wales. If the kings of Gwynedd were really
descended from the 'men of the north' their settlement in that region
is probably to be regarded as part of a much larger movement, of which
the traces elsewhere were obliterated by the English conquest.
CHAPTER VI.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Most of the heroic poems and stories which have come down to us contain

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: elements generally comprehended under the term 'folk-tale' (Märchen),

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: and it will be convenient at once to distinguish tales of this class

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: from popular tales in general. Under the latter term we may include

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: all stories which are frequently repeated without being committed to

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: writing. It is on such foundations probably that all the surviving

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: heroic poems are built. The lapse of time between the events narrated

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: and the composition of the poem may amount to weeks or to generations;

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: occurrence in poems and stories dealing with the gods, while similar

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: ideas are widely prevalent among primitive peoples at the present day.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Among other supernatural characteristics may be mentioned that of

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: invulnerability, through the use of magic which rendered all weapons

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: harmless--a feature found in Beowulf (in the case of Grendel) as well

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: as in later works. Often too heroes are capable of superhuman powers

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: of strength or endurance, as in Beow. 377 ff., 544 ff.[192], though

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: many of these cases may be set down to mere exaggeration. On the whole

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: however such characteristics are scarcely as prominent as they are in

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the heroic stories of other nations.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: The love of the marvellous is more strikingly displayed in Procopius'

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: account of Britain (_Goth._ IV 20) than in any of the poems which have

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: come down to us. In the first place he says that the whole country

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: beyond the great wall (i.e. the Roman Wall) was inhabited only by

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: snakes and wild beasts, and that if any man ventured there he would

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: die at once from the pestilential atmosphere. Then he goes on to say

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: that Britain was the dwelling place of the spirits of the dead, and

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: describes in detail how certain people who dwelt on the Frankish coast

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: ferried the souls across. As to the truth of this story Procopius

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: himself expresses scepticism; yet he states that he had heard it

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: from numerous witnesses. It is scarcely permissible therefore to

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: suppose that he had been victimised by a humorist. More probably he is

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: reporting stories actually current among the Teutonic soldiery in the

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Roman army, which doubtless contained adventurers from many distant

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: lands. In short we have here to do with folk-tales[193] which had

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: been localised in Britain and were believed to represent its condition

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: truly at the very time when Procopius was writing. It is exceedingly

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: remarkable that such stories should obtain credence at a time when,

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: as we know from more than one source, there was quite a considerable

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: amount of communication between Britain and the Continent. Indeed

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Procopius himself says that large numbers of English emigrants had

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: recently settled within the Frankish dominions.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: In the course of this chapter we have seen that many of

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: the heroic stories contain elements derived from myth and

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: folk-tale. The distinction which we have drawn between the two

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: categories is that only the former deals with definite--though

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: unhistorical--personalities[194]. It is commonly held that myth is

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: a necessary element in heroic stories; but this is a question which

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: we must reserve for discussion in the next chapter. Further, we have

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: seen that the presence of supernatural elements does not necessarily

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: mean that the stories in which they occur were composed or modified

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: long after the events which they relate; that, on the contrary, such

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: elements are to be found in contemporary or almost contemporary

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: narratives. They must be taken as faithful reflections of the beliefs

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: and ideas of an uncritical age. But it is scarcely correct to regard

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: these elements as the distinctive characteristics of heroic poetry.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: Their chief domain in reality is the folk-tale, a far more primitive

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: form of composition, which without doubt was in existence during the

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: same period. The truly distinctive characteristics of heroic poetry are

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.
line: rather those which differentiate it from the folk-tale.

Poem Title: SUPERNATURAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC STORIES.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[164] Under this heading we may include metrical compositions. The term
'folk-song' cannot conveniently be used here, as it has acquired a
wider signification.
[165] _Kilderne til Sakses Oldhistorie_, p. 18 ff.
[166] Ballads on heroic subjects may of course have begun quite early.
[167] Elsewhere this name occurs only in the genealogies, where it is
borne by an ancestor of Woden. It is possible however that in the Elegy
some unknown hero of the Geatas may be meant (cf. Beow. 640, 1785 etc.).
[168] This word is said to occur only here and in a following verse.
From the description the weapon seems to have been a kind of dirk with
a long wooden shaft.
[169] Fornmanna Sögur, III p. 204 ff. (especially p. 223 ff.).
[170] Cf. Brandl, _Grundriss d. germ. Philol._², II p. 993 f. The
following pages (995 f.) contain an admirable summary of the whole
question.
[171] Cf. Hansen, _Landnåm i Norge_, p. 160. For stories of monsters
which suggest savages, cf. Ketils S. Haengs, cap. 2 f., and Gríms S.
Loðinkinna, cap. 1.
[172] A somewhat similar account of Biarki's origin is given in the
(fifteenth century) Biarkarímur.
[173] _Tradunt relaciones antiquorum quod uir quidam nobilis, quem
Dominus permisit, contra solitum ordinem humane propaginis, ex quodam
albo urso patre, muliere generosa matre, procreari, Ursus genuit
Spratlingum; Spratlingus Ulsium; Ulsius Beorn, cognomento Beresune,
hoc est filius ursi. Hic Beorn Dacus fuit natione, comes egregius et
miles illustris. In signum autem illius diversitatis speciei ex parte
generantium produxerat ei natura paternas auriculas, sive ursi etc._
Michel, _Chroniques Anglo-normandes_, p. 104.
[174] _Illum maximum ursum ... cuius pater in silvis fertur puellam
rapuisse et ex ea Biernum regem Norweye genuisse._ ib. p. 7 f. A
similar story is told by Saxo (p. 345 f.) of the ancestry of Svend
Estrithson.
[175] Yet Hialti's third speech (p. 61) contains the words _igne ursos
arcere licet_, the significance of which is obscure. It is curious, as
Prof. Olrik (_Danmarks Heltedigtning_, p. 51) has pointed out, that
Hrólfs Saga (cap. 33) refers to bears in a corresponding place, though
the context is quite different.
[176] Prof. Olrik (_op. cit._, p. 45) says that Biarki's sleep is
certainly of a supernatural character and suggests that it is due to
magical arts on the part of the enemy.
[177] Cf. especially Yngl. S. 6: Othin's men went to battle without
mail-coats and were frenzied like dogs or wolves. They bit into their
shields and were as strong as bears or bulls. They made slaughter of
other men; but neither fire nor iron took effect upon them. This is
called _berserksgangr_.
[178] The identity of the two stories is shown by the fact that in both
cases Hialti is made to drink the creature's blood--a custom known in
Norway in comparatively recent times (cf. Olrik, _op. cit._, p. 118).
The Biarkarímur tell of two encounters, the first with a she-wolf, the
second between Hialti and a bear.
[179] Cf. the Cott. Gnomic Verses, 26 f.: _draca sceal on hlaewe frod
fraetwum wlanc_.
[180] It is generally held that this person's original name was Beowa
or Beaw. The latter is the form given in the genealogy in the Chronicle
(_ad ann._ 855); but in view of the many corruptions which this
genealogy has suffered it may very well be due to a scribal error for
_Beowa_. This again may be a hypocoristic form for _Beowulf_, though on
the other hand it is by no means impossible that the name of the son
of Scyld has been assimilated to that of the hero of the poem. But in
any case there does not seem to be any adequate ground for the commonly
accepted view that the adventure with Grendel originally belonged to
this person.
[181] In Skiöldunga Saga, Langfeðgatal etc. Halfdan's father is not
Friðfróði (Saxo's Frotho I) but Fróði hinn froekni (Saxo's Frotho IV),
the Froda of Beowulf.
[182] As regards Frotho's parentage--Saxo makes him son of Hadingus,
son of Gram, son of Scioldus. In Skiöldunga Saga, Langfeðgatal etc.
Friðfróði is son of Friðleifr, son of Skiöldr; while Fróði hinn froekni
is son of Friðleifr, son of Danr.
_Tantum pene uis celica pensat.
quippe unum e superis alieno corpore tectum
sacrilege necuere manus: sic numinis almi
interfector ades._
[184] We may compare the case of Apollo and the Python at Delphi, and
possibly the story of Thor (Miðgarðs véurr) and Miðgarðsormr. Note
should also be taken of the existence of a local tradition--going back
apparently to the Middle Ages--to the effect that the Isefjord was
formerly haunted by a monster which demanded a human victim from every
ship that passed. It was finally expelled by the arrival of the relics
of St Lucius, to whom Roeskilde cathedral is dedicated (cf. Sarrazin,
_Beowulf-Studien_, p. 10 ff.). The traditional burial-place of Fróði
the Peaceful is on the shore of the Roeskilde Fjord; but the two fjords
have a common entrance.
[185] It does not of course remove all difficulties. The chief of these
perhaps is the presence of Wiglaf, who seems clearly to belong to
Beowulf, the son of Ecgtheow. The discrepancy between the names Beowulf
and Fróði is of minor account, since the latter may very well have
originated in a title (cf. Beow. v. 2928). On the other hand if this
person is really a mythical national hero the name _Beowa_ (perhaps for
an earlier form _Biowi_) would seem more natural than _Beowulf_. Yet
there may have been intermediate stages between the original hero and
the person finally credited with the exploit.
[186] Thus upon some of these legends a good deal of light seems to be
thrown by certain usages cited by Mr Frazer in his _Lectures on the
Early History of the Kingship_, p. 180.
[187] Herodotus (III 116, IV 13, 27) speaks of a region in the extreme
north of Europe or Asia which was said to be inhabited by gold-guarding
griffins (χρυσοφύλακες γρύπες, cf. _goldweard_, Beow. 3082).
[188] Cf. the reference to the Gnomic verses quoted on p. 123, note.
[189] Epistola Synodi Carisiacensis ad Hludowicum regem Germaniae
directa (Mon. Germ., Legum Sect. II, Capit. Reg. Franc., Tom. II, p.
[190] _nos autem illos uidimus qui usque ad nostram aetatem durauerunt,
qui huic rei interfuerunt et nobis uiua uoce ueraciter sunt testati
quae audierunt atque uiderunt._
[191] Texts D, E, F. This entry seems to come from the Northumbrian
_Gesta_, which were probably composed not very long afterwards. The
last entry which we can trace is for the year 806.
[192] A curious light on the enormous strength ascribed to Beowulf is
thrown by a passage in the Liber Monstrorum (cf. p. 24). It is there
stated that Hygelac (Beowulf's uncle) was of such immense size that no
horse could carry him after he reached the age of twelve. His bones
were shown as a marvel to visitors.
[193] The folk-tale represented by the second story may of course be
derived ultimately from some ancient custom; cf. Beow. 26-52.
[194] Not, of course, personalities consciously invented by an
individual brain; these must be classed under fiction. On the other
hand myth must be held to include personifications of the heavenly
bodies and natural phenomena--as (e.g.) in Gylfaginning, cap. 10
ff. (from Vafþrúðnismál, etc.), and certain Lithuanian folk-songs
('Dainos')--in so far at least as such personifications are of popular
origin.
CHAPTER VII.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: We have now to consider the question whether myth is a necessary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: element in the formation of heroic poetry. It has been noticed that

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: historical persons figure in many stories of the Heroic Age, while

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: others do not contain a single character whose historical existence

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: can be authenticated. These latter stories are believed to be wholly

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: mythical in origin, though they may not show any supernatural features

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in their final form. But even in stories of the former type it is held

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that some of the characters are almost always of mythical origin,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and that their association with historical characters is a secondary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: development--due to confusion or to poetic imagination.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In the last chapter we put forward the view that Beowulf, the hero

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of the poem, has been confused with a mythical character of the same

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: name, and that the adventure with the dragon originally belonged to the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: latter. It can scarcely be doubted that Scyld Scefing, the father of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: this earlier Beowulf, was also a mythical character. The only element

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in his story common to English and Scandinavian tradition is that he is

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: regarded as the ancestor of the Scyldungas or Skiöldungar, the Danish

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: royal family, and all analogies suggest that he came into existence

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: as their eponymus. The brief account of him given in the poem might,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: except in two particulars, be applied to almost any successful king of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Heroic Age. One exception relates to the story of the funeral ship,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: on which the dead king's body is sent out to sea. In spite of Prof.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Olrik's doubts[195] I cannot but think that this is a reminiscence of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: ancient custom. The other is the reference to his arrival as an infant,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: likewise by sea--a story told more fully of Sceaf in certain English

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: chronicles. The only question here is between myth and folk-tale. The

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: story may fairly be classed under the latter head, though I think

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: its origin is ultimately to be sought in a ritual myth. Scandinavian

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: authorities, apart from Saxo[196], record nothing distinctive of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Skiöldr, except that he was a son of Othin and the husband of the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: goddess Gefion[197]--which again points to myth.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In Scyld-Skiöldr we have the case of an eponymous ancestor appearing in

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the introduction to a poem which deals largely with the fortunes of his

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: descendants. But there is no evidence that his own deeds ever formed

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the subject of an independent heroic poem. It would be somewhat hasty

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: therefore to use this case as an argument for the origin of characters

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: who are brought before us in the main action of heroic poems.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Next we may take the story of Weland, as to the mythical origin of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which nearly all scholars seem to be agreed. It has indeed a historical

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: or semi-historical connection in the fact that Weland is represented

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: as the father of Widia (Wudga), i.e. the early Gothic hero Vidigoia

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: mentioned by Jordanes (cf. p. 27); but this is held to be a secondary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: element in the story. In its original form the story is believed to

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: have dealt only with the incidents related in Völundarkviða, viz. (i)

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the adventure with the swan-maidens, (ii) Weland's imprisonment by

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Nithhad and his revenge[198]. Behind the story itself however there

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: lies a widespread belief in the existence of a supernatural smith of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: this name. Several places in Germany (Westphalia and Holstein) are

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: reputed to be the scene of his operations, while in this country he

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is connected with the cromlech called Wayland Smith, near Ashdown in

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Berkshire. In its ultimate origin this belief is traced to the myth of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: a fire-demon. Certainly it is to be noted that the name _Weland_ is of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: a very exceptional type--apparently participial in form. One can hardly

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: help suspecting that it once had a definite meaning, though this cannot

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: now be determined with certainty[199].

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Now there can be little doubt that the adventure with the swan-maidens

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is derived from a folk-tale. In this part of the story there is no

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: indication of a fire-demon, or even of a smith, while analogies for

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the incident are fairly common both in Teutonic lands and much farther

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: afield. We may confine our attention therefore to the second and better

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: known part--that which deals with Weland's imprisonment and revenge.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: It is manifest that this story departs very decidedly from the ordinary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: standard of heroic poetry--firstly in the fact that the hero is here

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: clearly represented as a smith, and secondly in the cruelty, treachery

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and vindictiveness ascribed to the chief characters. These are features

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which would be in place either in myth or folk-tale. But we may note

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: further that there are analogies for part of this story, just as much

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: as for the incident of the swan-maidens. As an example we may take

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Saxo's account of the robbing of Mimingus by Hotherus (p. 70 f.).

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Mimingus is a _satyrus_, i.e. clearly either an elf or dwarf, who

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: dwells in a cave in an almost inaccessible forest. Hotherus surprises

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and binds him and then takes away his sword and a magical ring. A

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: connection between the two stories is shown even in the name, for

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Weland's most famous sword is called Mimming[200]. For a more remote

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: parallel we may compare the story of Loki and Andvari. Indeed the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: spoiling of a dwarf is quite a common motif in Northern tales, while at

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the same time such beings are constantly credited with extraordinary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: skill in metallurgy. The distinctive feature in the story of Weland,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: apart from the revenge, is that sympathy is on the side of the smith.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: It is the end of the story--where Weland (Völundr) rises into the air

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and flies away--that is supposed to point most clearly to a fire-myth.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: But this feature cannot be traced except in the Norse version[201].

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Moreover here we have also the adventure with the flying swan-maidens,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in whose case there is no suspicion of such a myth. Setting aside this

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: incident the story is perfectly explicable as a folk-tale founded on

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: actual experience. There can be no doubt that in the Heroic Age--and

line: regard to the character of the supernatural disguise. In the Norse

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: version, where the two incidents are combined, Sigurðr and Gunnarr have

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: exchanged forms; in the German Gunther is present in both cases, though

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Siegfried, who has rendered himself invisible, is the real actor.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Several other important differences between the two versions have

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: already been noted (p. 13 f.). In addition to these each version has of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: course many characters and incidents peculiar to itself.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Of the discrepancies enumerated on p. 13 f. the fifth is by far the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: most important, since Kriemhild's revenge for Siegfried forms the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: central motif of the second half of the Nibelungenlied. In the Norse

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: version no such central motif is to be found. In the prose piece

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Dráp Niflunga Atli's conduct is attributed to revenge for the death

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of Brynhildr, while in Völsunga Saga it is ascribed to his lust for

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Sigurðr's gold. But in the poems themselves no real explanation is

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: given, and the connection between this part of the story and that

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: relating to Sigurðr is scarcely more than a personal one--viz. that

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Guðrún, Gunnarr and Högni figure in both. This however is a phenomenon

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: for which parallels are to be found in other heroic stories, e.g.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: those of Beowulf and Weland. It is now held--and doubtless rightly--by

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the majority of scholars that the unity of interest imparted to

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Nibelungenlied by the motif of Kriemhild's revenge is a later

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: improvement on the somewhat disconnected story given in the Edda. For

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: our present purpose however the question is immaterial, since it is not

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: contended that this part of the story is of mythical origin.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In spite of the discrepancies noted above it cannot be denied that

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the two versions contain a remarkable number of identical features in

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: this part of the story--a fact which renders all the more striking the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: very slight amount of agreement in the part dealing with the hero's

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: early adventures. Unless all analogies are misleading the conclusion to

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which we are driven is that the original story began more or less where

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Nibelungenlied begins, and that the hero's youthful adventures

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: are later accretions, such as we see gathering round the childhood or

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: ancestry of other heroes, e.g. Biarki (cf. p. 120). We may add also the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: cases of Starkaðr, Hagen in Kûdrûn and perhaps Witege (cf. p. 135).

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: They appear to be derived, in part at least, from folk-tales. One of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: these--affecting probably only the Norse version--may be identified

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: with the Scandinavian story of Svipdagr and Menglöð (cf. p. 12), a

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: variety perhaps of that of the Sleeping Beauty. Another is that of the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: forest dwarf who forges or preserves a magical sword. We may note

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that in Thiðreks Saga the smith is called Mimir, a name which recalls

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Saxo's Mimingus (cf. p. 133)[217]. The story of the treasure-guarding

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: dragon may also be included in this category, though strictly perhaps

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: it belongs rather to popular belief than to folk-tale. From the fact

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that some of these elements are common to both versions we may probably

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: infer that the process of accretion had begun before the story reached

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the North. Yet there do seem to be some indications of a reflex

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: influence[218]--from the North or some region exposed to Northern

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: influence--upon the development of the story in Germany.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In addition to folk-tales we must take into consideration also a

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: tendency which is often associated with them--the desire to account for

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: an obscure name. This seems to be the most reasonable explanation of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the names _Nibelung_ and _Nibelunge_ in the first part of the German

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: epic and _Nybling_ in the ballad--all denoting the original owners of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the treasure. We have seen that in the Norse version, as well as in the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: latter half of the Nibelungenlied, _Niflungar_ means the Burgundians.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: May we not suppose that it was really a dynastic name[219] like

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: _Scyldungas_, _Uffingas_, _Merewioingas_? In that case of course _hodd

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Niflunga_ (_hort der Nibelunge_) ought to mean the family treasure of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the Burgundian kings. But is it quite certain that Atlakviða does not

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: use it in this sense? That it is identified with Fáfnir's treasure in

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: later authorities may be due to subsequent German influence. As for

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the fact that the name _Nibelunge_ is used for the Burgundians only

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in the second half of the German epic, may not this spring from some

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: stylistic peculiarities of the 'common foundation'? It is not necessary

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: to suppose that the latter was all the work of one author or even of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: one generation.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: In dealing with questions such as these we cannot hope to get beyond a

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: reasonable hypothesis, since the paucity of common features between

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the two versions admits of few definite conclusions. But from the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: time when the hero arrives at the Burgundian court the case is quite

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: different. In spite of certain discrepancies there is no difficulty in

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: determining the main outline of the story. Even in the most important

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: point of all--the true cause of the hero's death--the two versions are

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: really in full agreement. Gutthormr does the deed in one version, Hagen

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in the other; but in both alike it arises out of the bitter resentment

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: cherished by Brynhildr, owing to the deception which has been practised

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: upon her. We have seen that this motif is incompatible with the current

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: mythological interpretation of the story. But more than this, it is

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: plainly not a motif derived from mythology at all, but from real life.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: It must not be overlooked that the Brynhildr and Högni of the Norse

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: version are in the nature of character-studies. Both appeal to our

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: sympathies, though we do not approve of the actions which they commit

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: or allow. Here we are in a region of thought as alien as possible to

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: that of the folk-tale. But it is also alien to that period of thought,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which was most open to the influence of folk-tales, the period which we

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: have called Stage III in the history of German poetry. In such a period

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the person who destroyed the hero must necessarily be a villain as

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: black as Hell. Between the instigator of the deed and the perpetrator,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: who by this time was Hagen--whether this was so originally or not is

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: immaterial--the choice was made, not unnaturally in the circumstances,

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: in favour of the latter, while the former was allowed, awkwardly

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: enough, to drop out of the story. Thus the peculiarities of the German

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: version may be explained quite naturally as modifications of an earlier

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: form similar to the other--modifications necessitated by the conditions

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: under which heroic poetry was preserved in Germany. The effect produced

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is somewhat similar to that which would be obtained by converting a

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: modern problem play into a popular melodrama.

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: The conclusion then to which we are brought is that the supposed

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: traces of myth, so far as they have any foundation at all, are due

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: to late accretions to the story, while the central motif in both

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: versions alike is by no means of a mythical character, but essentially

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: human. Consequently the story of Sigurðr stands quite on a line with

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the other stories of the Heroic Age. Most of them contain elements

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: which may be interpreted as mythical; but these elements are always

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: most prominent in the latest forms of the story. It must not escape

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: notice that those scholars who most strongly uphold the mythical

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: interpretation base their arguments chiefly on such works as the

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Seyfridslied and Thiðreks Saga af Bern. The explanation is that

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: myth is a growth which requires time to develop. Even Beowulf is no

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: real exception to the general rule, for in the latter part the hero

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is probably confused with a namesake whose story may have been of

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: considerable antiquity, while the only character in the poem who is

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: quite clearly of mythical origin is the first ancestor of the Danish

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: royal family[220].

Poem Title: MYTHICAL ELEMENTS IN THE HEROIC POEMS.

line: FOOTNOTES:
[195] _Danmarks Heltedigtning_, p. 248 ff. With this subject I have
already dealt in _The Origin of the English Nation_, p. 287 f.
[196] Saxo (p. 11 f.) records several incidents of which we know
nothing from other sources. He represents Skiöldr (_Scioldus_) as a
reformer of the laws, but not as the first king.
[197] This is stated only in Ynglinga Saga (cap. 5); but the question
to be asked is whether it is likely that such a combination would be
invented in late times.
[198] From Deor's Elegy and the picture on the Franks casket in the
British Museum it is clear that almost all the main features of the
second part of the story were known in England. Reminiscences of the
first part occur in the medieval German poem _Herzog Friedrich von
Schwaben_.
[199] It is usually connected with O. Norse _vél_, 'contrivance,'
'artifice.'
[200] Waldhere, I 2 f.; Thiðreks Saga, cap. 23 etc.
[201] In Thiðreks Saga, cap. 30, Weland flies away in a garment which
he has made from feathers collected for him by his brother Egill. It
is thought by some that the engraver of the Franks casket had the same
story in mind, since a figure catching birds is represented behind the
form of Beaduhild.
[202] It is commonly held that this account has been influenced
somehow by the story of Weland. If so it is a valuable illustration of
the process discussed in p. 119 ff. above. But the view seems to me
somewhat far-fetched.
[203] Waldhere is the only English poem which mentions Weland as the
father of Widia; but I cannot admit that there is any ground for
supposing this poem to have had a different origin from the rest (cf.
p. 57 f.). The variant forms _Widia_--_Wudga_ may be explained by
English sound-laws, while _Niðhad_, whatever its explanation, occurs
also in Deor's Elegy.
[204] Saxo (p. 158 ff.) connects the story with the reign of Frotho III
(Fróði the Peaceful), and this may be an ancient feature, as Fruote von
Tenemarke appears as one of Hetel's chief men in Kûdrûn.
[205] "Ein Bild des unaufhörlichen, allgemeinen, aber nie entschiedenen
Kampfes entgegengesetzter Mächte, des Aufgangs und des Niedergangs,
des Entstehens und Vergehens, des Seins und Nichtseins" (Müllenhoff,
_ZfdA._ XXX 229). Prof. Sijmons (_Grundriss_, III 711, where
this interpretation is quoted with approval) regards the story
as 'tiefsinnig.' I confess the interpretation is too deep for
my comprehension. A totally different view is taken in Panzer's
_Hilde-Gudrun_, where the origin of the story is traced to a folk-tale
(p. 250 ff.). It seems to me that this theory is open to somewhat the
same objection as the other, namely that it is founded too much upon
features peculiar to one or other version. At the same time I doubt
whether Wate's original connection with the story can be properly
inferred from Wids. 21 f. The influence of folk-tales is clear enough
in both versions of the story, but I think it is secondary.
[206] From a passage in Lamprecht's _Alexander_ (v. 1321), a work of
the twelfth century, it appears that Hagen (Högni) was killed in the
earlier German version of the story.
[207] For the endless battle there are a number of parallels; cf.
Panzer, _op. cit._, p. 327 ff. (also Pausanias, I 32. 3, with Mr
Frazer's note).
[208] There is also a Polish version which has several peculiarities of
its own but shows no special affinity with the form of the story found
in Thiðreks Saga.
[209] The early North German version of this story, represented by the
Annals of Quedlinburg (cf. p. 37, note), apparently made Eormenric
perish in the fight.
[210] It is held by many that this name was originally connected with
_Wascono lant_, an early German name for Aquitaine (Gascony) and that
the introduction of the Vosges (_Wasgunberg_) was later and due to
the confusion of two similar names. But, if there has been any such
confusion at all, chronological considerations render it far more
probable that the transference was in the reverse direction.
[211] Among the exceptions mention may be made especially of an
interesting paper by Prof. Mogk in _Neue Jahrbücher_, I pp. 68-80.
[212] It is stated however that Seyfrid thought that it belonged to the
dragon. Hence this story is often connected with the Norse version.
[213] The only German evidence worth consideration is the fact that
certain rocks in the Taunus and the Palatinate are called the 'bed'
or 'chair of Brynhildr' (_lectulus Brunnihilde_, _Brinholdestul_) in
medieval documents. But I do not see how these names can prove anything
more than the popularity of the story. In all lands it is customary to
adopt such names from remarkable characters, whatever their origin may
be. We may think of the cave of Frederic Barbarossa at Berchtesgaden or
the numerous places called after Robin Hood in England.
[214] Helgakv. Hund. I 48, Atlamál 88. In the former case the name is
used quite generally, like _Ylfingar_ in the same poem. In the latter
_Hniflungr_ is the name of Högni's son.
[215] There was of course another heroic character of the same name;
but this does not meet the objection.
[216] On both these occasions the Nibelungenlied mentions also a girdle.
[217] It seems likely that Mímir was the dwarf's original name and that
Saxo has given him a name which properly belonged to his sword; cf. the
phrase _Hoddmímis holt_ (Vafðr. 45), etc.
[218] E.g. the name Schilbung and the references to Norway. The story
of Sigemund and the dragon also belongs to a maritime region.
[219] Cf. Skaldsk. 42: "Gunnarr and Högni are called Niflungar and
Giúkungar."
[220] Cf. Schütte, _Oldsagn om Godtjod_, pp. 35-38, where it is well
pointed out that all the clearest cases of myth in early Teutonic
records belong to stories dealing with the origin of nations or
dynasties. "Den eneste udtrykkelige Myte, der udenfor specielt
religiøse Gøremål har været episk frugtbar i Folkevandringstiden er
Ophavsmyten."
CHAPTER VIII.

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: The question how far the use of fiction was permitted in heroic poetry

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: is of course one to which we cannot possibly hope to give a definite

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: answer. All poetry which deserves the name claims to do something

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: more than provide a bare record of facts. According to the ancient

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: definition[221] its proper function is to express the universal rather

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: than the particular--what may happen or may have happened rather

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: than what has happened. Some freedom of play for the imagination is

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: therefore essential. These remarks hold good for early Teutonic poetry

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: just as much as for Greek. If we could recover the poems recited in

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: Attila's presence (cf. p. 84) we should doubtless find that they

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: contained far more than a mere statement of facts. In the works which

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: have come down to us however the degree to which freedom is allowed

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: to the imagination varies very greatly from case to case. Thus in the

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: poem on the battle of Brunanburh it is restricted within comparatively

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: narrow limits, while in the almost contemporaneous Hákonarmál the

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: historical fact on which the poem is based is very largely obscured by

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: a wholly fictitious narrative. We may naturally expect that the authors

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: of heroic poems likewise differed in the treatment of their subjects,

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: though not necessarily to the same degree.

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: As an instance of a poem which obviously contains a large amount of

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: fiction we can hardly do better than take the Anglo-Saxon Widsith. The

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: greater part of this poem consists, as we have seen, of a speech by a

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: minstrel enumerating the various peoples and princes with whom he was

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: acquainted. Amongst others he states that he had visited the Gothic

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: king Eormenric (who died before 375), the Burgundian king Guthhere

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: (who died about 437) and the Langobardic king Aelfwine (who died about

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: 572). Now it is commonly held that the poem is of composite formation,

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and there can be little doubt that additions have been made to it from

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: time to time. This will account for statements such as those given

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: above and, though it does not prevent them from being fictitious, it

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: may enable us to form some idea as to how fiction was used. Poets of

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the seventh century probably possessed no chronological tables, and

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: consequently they may not have been aware that the foreign princes of

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: whom they were speaking belonged to quite different ages. Yet without

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: such knowledge the visits of the minstrel may clearly be placed among

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: the 'things which may have happened.' What these poets certainly did

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: know was that Eormenric was a prominent figure in some traditional

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: stories, Guthhere in others. It did no violence to the story (μῦθος)

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: itself to bring an anonymous character into contact both with Eormenric

Poem Title: THE USE OF FICTION IN THE HEROIC POEMS.
line: and Guthhere, although doubtless no one would have done this while

γὰρ ποίησις μᾶλλον τὰ καθόλου, ἡ δ' ἱστορία τὰ καθ' ἕκαστον λέγει.

to various ages introduced by the expression _innweorud Earmanrices_
('Eormenric's household-troop'); but this expression need not be
interpreted literally with reference to the whole list.
[223] Frotho I and Frotho III were no doubt originally identical; but
the confusion extends also (especially in Skiöldunga Saga) to Frotho
IV (the Froda of Beowulf), who cannot reasonably be connected with the
others (cf. p. 124, note).
[224] The MS. here (v. 62) is defective, but no other interpretation is
probable.

in the verses and one in the introduction. Is it really impossible that
the name has been altered by a scribe familiar with Thiðreks Saga? Cf.
Jónsson, _Oldn. Litteraturs Historie_, I 295.
[226] This tendency is doubtless due largely to the influence of
romantic poetry.

that the Bernician king Ida is said to have had two sons called
Theodric and Theodhere. But is not the date rather early? The
occurrence of the name _Sigesteb_ in the council of Ecgberht, king of
Wessex (Birch, 395), is perhaps stronger evidence. The name _Omulung_
which is found more than a century earlier (Birch, 76, 116) scarcely
necessitates acquaintance with the story of Dietrich von Bern.
[228] The case would be different if it could be proved that the person
described as _skati Marika_ (_Maringa_) in the inscription of Rök was
Dietrich von Bern.
[229] It is worth noting that in Widsith, v. 115, Seafola and Theodric
(i.e. Saben and Wolfdietrich) appear among the Gothic heroes.
[230] This version (represented by the Ann. Quedl., cf. p. 37, note),
like the Norse, added a third brother, though he bears a different
name. But the person killed, whose name is not given, is said to have
been the father of the brothers, not their sister.
[231] _Hermanaricus rex Gothorum ... de Hunorum ... aduentu dum
cogitat, Rosomonorum gens infida, quae tunc inter alias illi famulatum
exhibebat, tali eum nanciscitur occasione decipere. dum enim quandam
mulierem, Sunildam nomine, ex gente memorata, pro mariti fraudulento
discessu rex furore commotus equis ferocibus inligatam incitatisque
cursibus per diuersa diuelli praecepisset, fratres eius Sarus et Ammius
germanae obitum uindicantes, Hermanarici latus ferro petierunt; quo
uulnere saucius, aegram uitam corporis imbecillitate contraxit.... inter
haec Hermanaricus tam uulneris dolorem, quam etiam Hunorum incursiones
non ferens ... defunctus est_ (cap. 24).
[232] The Frankish queen Brunhild was put to death in a similar way in
the year 613. We may also compare the Thuringian atrocities described
by Gregory of Tours (III 7).
[233] The chief exception is the part played by Wiglaf; possibly also
the incident of the cowardly knights.
[234] ἡ τῶν πραγμάτων σύστασις (Aristotle, _Poet._ VI 9).
[235] For the case of Widsith see p. 56 f. Supernatural beings, such
as Grendel, and mythical personages of the past, such as Scyld, cannot
fairly be regarded as exceptions, since it is not at all likely
that they were invented by the poet himself. They figure largely in
skaldic poems of the Viking Age (e.g. Hákonarmál) which probably never
introduce fictitious contemporary characters. On the other hand some of
the characters in the Edda poems may have been invented in the North.
[236] This must be emphasized because one constantly finds theories of
fictitious origin introduced with some sentence such as the following:
'It has not yet been proved that this story has any historical
foundation.' Such an attitude seems to me not only unreasonable but
wrong in principle.

the beginning of the ninth century, and _Unwine_ (_Unwenes_, Gen.), the

Germany during the eighth and ninth centuries.
[238] Prof. Olrik (_Danmarks Heltedigtning_, p. 25 ff.) suggests
further that he was the instigator of a quarrel between Hrothwulf
and Hrothgar or his sons. But I cannot help thinking that his
interpretation of vv. 1166 ff., ingenious as it undoubtedly is, goes a

(cf. A.-S. _Hemma_, _Hemmi_). But in that case of course we shall have
to conclude that the name had been familiar for some time before it
came to Jordanes' knowledge.
[241] No argument can be based upon the name _Suanailta_ which is
found in a document at St Gall dating from 786 (in conjunction with
other names which show a knowledge of the story of Eormenric), for it
may contain either _swan-_ or _sōn-_. It is admitted that the name
_Swanahilt_ was in use.

accounted for! Had it not been for the incidental reference to this
king in Ammianus Marcellinus' history, nothing could possibly have
saved him from being regarded as a purely fictitious personage.
[243] In Ekkehard's case the influence of Stage III is supplemented
or amended by erudition. The national names which he gives (_Franci_,
_Burgundia_, etc.) are accommodated to the political divisions of his
own time.
[244] Cf. Zeuss, _Die Deutschen und die Nachbarstämme_, p. 582 ff.,

[245] It is impossible here to enter into a criticism of theories such
as those brought forward in Boer's _Untersuchungen über den Ursprung
und die Entwickelung der Nibelungensage_.
[246] Owing to the great lacuna in the MS. of the Edda (cf. p. 13) the
poems which dealt with this part of the story are lost.
[247] The story may have come to the North in two different forms, one
of which related the wooing of Brynhildr by Sigurðr, while the other,
a later form, contained the incident of the supernatural disguise. But
it is also possible that even the original poem or poems on the subject
dealt with this incident, though without altogether suppressing the
previous relations between Sigurðr and Brynhildr.
[248] There is no need to assume that the story of Guthhere's death was
embodied in the same poem, though the two were doubtless connected from
